thread.title: US stocks end higher despite weak oil shares
thread.title_full: US stocks end higher despite weak oil shares

title: US stocks end higher despite weak oil shares
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Oct 19, 2015, 22:05 BST - UK Markets closed US stocks end higher despite weak oil shares AFP â€“ 18 minutes ago View Photo 

US stocks finished modestly higher Monday as gains in tech shares offset weakness in petroleum-linked equities following weak Chinese economic data. 
The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 14.57 points (0.08 percent) to 17,230.54. 
The broad-based S&P 500 edged up 0.55 (0.03 percent) to 2,033.66, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 18.78 (0.38 percent) at 4,905.47. 
Petroleum-linked shares fell with oil prices after the Chinese government reported the weakest quarterly growth in more than six years. ExxonMobil was the Dow laggard, down 1.8 percent, and Chevron (Swiss: CVX.SW - news ) shed 1.4 percent on the blue-chip index, while EOG Resources (NYSE: EOG - news ) fell 3.1 percent. 
But tech shares were broadly higher, with larger gains for Netflix (Hanover: NFC.HA - news ) (+2.7 percent) and Priceline (+3.0 percent). Apple (LSE: 0R2V.L - news ) rose 0.6 percent. 
Morgan Stanley (Xetra: 885836 - news ) sank 4.8 percent after third-quarter earnings came in at $740 million, dropping more than 50 percent from the year-ago period on weak trading results. 
Canadian drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals International (NYSE: VRX - news ) fell 7.7 percent as it signaled it expects to dispose of a business associated with large drug price increases and foresees much more modest price hikes in the future. 
United Continental (NYSE: UAL - news ) , parent of United Airlines, rose 1.4 percent after announcing it would outline more details about its corporate governance processes later in the day or Tuesday in light of the emergency hospitalization last week of new chief executive Oscar Munoz. 
Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) of Weight Watchers International (NYSE: WTW - news ) more than doubled to $13.92 from $6.79 on news of a partnership with much-admired US television talk show host Oprah Winfrey, who will take a 10 percent stake in the struggling company and plans to "candidly share her experiences" employing its weight-management programs. Winfrey will also join the board of the company. 
PMC-Sierra jumped 14.8 percent after chipmaker Microsemi said it had offered to acquire the data storage and cloud computing company for about $2.2 billion. Microsemi fell 5.4 percent. 
The Microsemi offer follows the October 5 announcement that PMC-Sierra reached a deal to be acquired by Skyworks Solutions (Xetra: AWM.DE - news ) for $2 billion in cash. Skyworks fell 2.2 percent. 
Bond prices were mixed. The yield on the 10-year US Treasury dropped to 2.02 percent from 2.03 percent Friday, while the 30-year held steady at 2.88 percent. Bond prices and yields move inversely.
